channel.title: What's your experience level?
channel.description: So I'm fairly new on this community. I'm looking for some advice and other tips for making true music. So I made this poll for whoever can help and that I have an idea of your experience level. [poll type=regular max=20 public=true] * Professional * Non-Professonal [/poll]

item.title: What's your experience level?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Seconded (kinda).
Lead melodies are often the key takeaway from a track. It helps if it’s relatively easy to memorise and hum/whistle/sing along to.

Look into how to write ‘hooks’. Hooks can be anything that catches the listener’s attention and makes them want mimic it. They’re often the lead melody, especially the lead vocal melody in the chorus of a song - though not always.

(I’ve been thinking about exactly this topic lately. I feel that hooks, especially melodic hooks, are something that don’t seem to appear often in tracks within this community. Tracks, including many of my own, seem to be more ‘textured’ or chord-led. And that can sometimes make tracks feel indistict.
I’m trying to be more conscious of them in my own work without mechanically trying to be ‘catchy’ - although ‘catchy’ shouldn’t be seen as a dirty word.)

I was thinking of starting a thread about hooks or adding some hook-related stuff to the thread below (which is worth checking out).

Post writing and production tips

I also think that Vox’s Earworm series is worth checking out.

Read full topic

item.title: What's your experience level?
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Audiotool is some cool stuff man, a little unfriendly having to click click click click click click everything but it’s like Reason in your browser. It’s pretty incredible. Pound for pound Auxy is easier and wayyyy faster.

The best thing with Auxy is just trust your ears. Play with the key, tempo, scale. Sometimes I write a whole track and then mess with these things and it sounds WAY different than what I originally did (sometimes better, sometimes worse). Experimentation is key

Read full topic

item.title: What's your experience level?
item.dc:creator: Break_N_Chains
item.description:
Okay thanks, it helps to have friendly people help. I started making music on audiotool and it wasnt the best starting software for me. Auxy is much easier but I notice that my songs are to long or repeat alot of the same cords throughout the whole song. Im looking to learn professional techniques and eventually make quality music.

Read full topic
